title: Dow, S&P 500 Decline as Oil Slides

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Purdue Defends Sackler Deal; Chip Startup Seeks Chapter 11 Sale; Frontline Worker Health Plan Dissolves
summary: Purdue Pharma defended its $4.5 billion settlement with its Sackler family owners. A semiconductor chip inspection startup filed for chapter 11, racing to close a sale. And a self-insured health plan covering thousands of essential workers is shutting down for good, after the bailout funds it hopes for never materialized.

title: Rents Surge, Adding Fuel to U.S. Inflation; Wall Street Watching Fed’s Reverse Repo Facility
summary: Housing is emerging as the biggest wildcard for inflation in the U.S. over the next year, and in recent months housing-cost trends point to upward price pressures. While landlords lost any pricing power during the pandemic as vacancy rates jumped, that began to change earlier this year as demand for new leases soared. And, of course, home prices never missed a beat. Meanwhile, spare cash keeps piling overnight into the Fed’s reverse repo facility, and that has many portfolio managers on edge and some analysts warning the markets for short-term funding appear to be vulnerable to disruption.

title: China’s Producer Prices Jump Despite Efforts to Cool Commodities Costs
summary: Factory-gate prices rose at an unexpectedly fast clip in July, matching the highest level in more than 12 years as crude oil and coal prices soared—though economists say the price pickup is unlikely to last.

summary: Calling it a ‘targeted corporate user fee’ doesn’t change the reality.

title: Trump Sticks With Fundraising Gimmick Despite DOJ Crackdown

title: Australia Takes Center Stage in Global Deals Spree
summary: The volume of mergers and acquisitions in Australia is already at its highest annual level on record with nearly five months of the year to go.

title: Brazil’s Central Bank Raises Benchmark Rate to 5.25%, Sees More Hikes Coming

summary: The S&P 500 fell on concerns as coronavirus cases spread and data showed the private sector added fewer jobs than economists expected in July.

title: Fuel-Efficiency Standards Are Set to Get Tougher. The Question Is by How Much.
summary: Auto industry pushes for middle ground as environmentalists seek aggressive mileage targets. The administration’s stricter rules could come as early as this week.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Nine Point Energy’s Bankruptcy Sale Ducks $150 Million Pipeline Claim
summary: A pipeline company that built an energy transport service for Nine Point Energy isn’t a secured creditor and has no right to payment in the driller’s bankruptcy sale, a federal judge ruled. Elsewhere, WSJ Pro Bankruptcy recaps court action affecting a pollution lawsuit against YPF, the Petters Ponzi scheme and a freshly bankrupt apparel business.

title: News Corp to Buy OPIS for $1.15 Billion

title: A Cash-Strapped Corner of China Finds a Financial Tonic—Hard Liquor
summary: The rise of China’s biggest liquor company,  Kweichow Moutai, has been a gift for the indebted province that is the company’s majority shareholder. “There is a lot of pressure to share the joy in Guizhou,” says one analyst.

title: Towns Trying to Ban Natural Gas Face Resistance in Push for All-Electric Homes
summary: Massachusetts is emerging as a hot spot in the battle over phasing out gas for home cooking and heating in favor of electricity, with opponents worried about higher costs and unfamiliar technologies.

title: Fed to Wrap Up Policy Meeting With Taper Timeline in Focus; Hot Housing Market Lets Banks Sell Mortgage Risk
summary: The Fed will release its policy statement at 2 p.m. Eastern time. Most of the focus is likely to center on Chairman Jerome Powell’s news conference at 2:30 p.m., including any comments he makes about the Fed’s stance toward tapering its $120 billion a month in bond purchases. The meeting is wrapping up after durable-goods data yesterday pointed to continued strength in the U.S. economy. Meanwhile, a red-hot housing market is letting banks bundle and sell default risk on mortgage loans to investors.

title: Glencore Probe Yields Charges Against Another Former Trader

summary: Lawmakers on Capitol Hill have been bogged down in infrastructure negotiations for months, but private-equity firms are not waiting for a bill to invest. Today, WSJ Pro Private Equity’s Luis Garcia reports on three major investments by EQT AB in the U.S. infrastructure sector totaling roughly $12 billion. Next, I report on the latest deal in the red-hot market for general-partner stakes: Azimut Alternative Capital Partners, an Italian group formed two years ago to invest in midmarket sponsors, buying a stake in asset-based lender Pathlight Capital. Finally, the Journal’s Amrith Ramkumar reports that AdTheorent Inc., an advertising-technology company majority owned by H.I.G. Capital, is nearing a sale to a blank-check company at a price tag of around $1 billion.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Texas Co-op Fights $1.9 Billion Winter Storm Bill; Oil Refinery Wants Sponsor Shielded From Lawsuits

title: Aon, Willis Towers Scrap $30 Billion Merger

title: PE Daily: Hellman & Friedman Raises $24.4 Billion | GA Targets Climate Change | Level Equity Seeks $900 Million | David Spreng Talks Venture Debt
summary: Private-equity fundraising continues at a breakneck pace, with news of a massive fund from Hellman & Friedman. As Chris Cumming reports, the San Francisco firm raised $24.4 billion for its latest offering, thanks in part to a massive commitment from Hellman & Friedman itself. On a slightly smaller level, Preeti Singh has news of two new fund formation efforts, one by General Alantic and another from Level Equity. Finally, in the last installment of our private-equity at midyear series, Runway Growth Capital’s David Spreng discusses the rapid growth in the venture debt market and its implications for investors.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Student Loan Borrower Wins Appeal; Wall Street Welcomes Back Junk Energy Bonds
summary: A consensus strengthened within federal appeals courts that private educational loans can be discharged through bankruptcy, a glimmer of hope for some borrowers amid continued inaction on student debt from the elected branches.

title: No Fed Policy Shift Despite Inflation Surge; Senate Confirms Former Fed Economist for Key Treasury Post
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell told the Senate Banking Committee it would be an error to overreact to the recent surge in inflation. He indicated that the Fed was in no hurry to adjust its policies, and would have a better grasp of how the reopening was proceeding by year’s end. Meanwhile, the Senate confirmed former Fed economist Nellie Liang in a role that puts her at the forefront of efforts to manage the soaring federal debt.

title: Powell Says Fed Still Expects Inflation to Ease; Bank of Canada Paring Its Bond Buying
summary: It’s day two of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s briefing for lawmakers, and he may get some more questions about the inflation outlook and whether the Fed will start paring its $120 billion a month in bond purchases. Yesterday, Mr. Powell said inflation has been higher and more persistent than the central bank had expected, and that the Fed is still a ways off from reducing its asset purchases. He also said the purchases help create a low-rate environment. Elsewhere, the Bank of Canada left its main interest rate unchanged and said it would reduce the amount of bonds it buys a week to 2 billion Canadian dollars, or the equivalent of $1.6 billion, from C$3 billion.

title: Wall Street Opens Back Up to Oil and Gas—but Not for Drilling

summary: Data showing that U.S. inflation accelerated in June sharpened the focus on Fed Chairman Jerome Powell’s appearance before the House Financial Services Committee today. title: PE Daily: Hg Bets $1 Billion on InsightSoftware | Ben Meng’s New Groove | Sageview Backs Specright | Oil Refinery Files for Bankruptcy
summary: This morning brings two new private-equity-backed software deals, albeit at different ends of the size spectrum. Our own Chris Cumming has news of a $1 billion investment from Hg into insightsoftware, a software provider that caters to chief financial officers. The deal values the company at some $4 billion. Meanwhile, Maria Armental reports on a $30 million funding round led by Sageview Capital for Specright, a software company that helps businesses manage their supply chains. Also in today’s news, an oil refinery backed by EIG Global Energy Partners has filed for bankruptcy, Andrew Scurria writes for WSJ Pro Bankruptcy, and Dawn Lim has an update on Ben Meng, the former chief investment officer at the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, who is joining Franklin Resources Inc.

Richmond Fed chief Thomas Barkin said the labor market needs further improvement before the central bank should reduce its bond buying. And American families and companies are both grappling with higher inflation.

title: Florida Pension System’s John Bradley Builds Conviction Around Oil and Gas
summary: WSJ Pro Private Equity caught up with John Bradley, senior investment officer, private equity at the Florida State Board of Administration to learn more about how the roughly $194.7 billion pension system is positioning its private-equity portfolio.

title: Strong U.S. Recovery Aids Growth in Canada, Mexico
summary: Central bank officials in both Mexico and Canada have raised their forecasts for economic growth in their respective countries, in part because of the strong U.S. rebound.
